title: Usernames still visible on report export pdf despite "I want to redact all usernames" is selected

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**

Hi Team,

Export report via .pdf still disclosing the reporter username despite I exported it with __"I want to redact all usernames"__ being selected to redact all the usernames.

{F2475645}

### Steps To Reproduce

1. Login and try to export any report using export as .pdf
2. Select "I want to redact all usernames"
3. Check the exported .pdf report is still disclosing the username of researcher

https://hackerone.com/reports/<REPORT-ID>.pdf?redact_usernames=true&pdf_type=reporter

PoC screenshot below:

█████

The .pdf looks messy (maybe design issue) but if you will take a look at __Reported by:__ section at the report header, you will see: `<REDACTED> (<REDACTED>j<REDACTED>a<REDACTED>p<REDACTED>z<REDACTED>)` If you removed the `<REDACTED>` it will show the username `japz`.

If you removed all `<REDACTED>`, you will see something like the screenshot below:

█████

## Impact

Information Disclosure

activities.message: Changing `Attack Complexity` to high and User `Interaction Required` because the user needs to share the .pdf

Hi @h1_analyst_charlie

Thanks, let me know if you are having trouble reproducing the PoC or if you need more information. I would be happy to help.

Regards,
@japz

Hi @h1_analyst_charlie 

Any updates on this ? , @security's average time to Triage is supposed to be 2 days.

I am attaching video PoC, since you haven't mentioned if you are able to reproduce the vulnerability.

███

Let me know if you have any questions.
Hi @h1_analyst_charlie - do we have any news on this ?

Hi @h1_analyst_charlie

Looks like my vulnerability submission was fix for all newly disclosed report ?

Any updates on this please ?

Thanks
Please note that tagging usernames is also affected using `@` symbol (ex: `@username`)

@h1_analyst_charlie @security

My submission is resolved already, the __"I want to redact all usernames"__ feature was removed and this completely resolved the vulnerability.
Hi @japz - we did not look at this report yet - I'm not sure who owns this feature but I will see if we can find it to get extra context on timeline and how this vulnerability was discovered/fixed.
Hi @zerotea - any news ? are you able to check it ? Thanks

Hi @zerotea @h1_analyst_charlie - I was wondering if there are any news, it was submitted for almost 10 days ago. The vulnerability looks like being resolved and 2 of HackerOne team member (analyst and internal) already replied but the report status still not even changed to `Pending program review` ?
Hi @zerotea - do we have any news on this ?

Hi @zerotea - I hate to ask an update again, but this was submitted 14 days ago (2 weeks already) and the report seems to be fix for 1 week but the report still in `New` status until now.

I would appreciate if you can give me an update on this one. Regards

Hi, -- you're right, this should have been in that status (pending program review) a while ago (7 days ago). I can see a "Revert PDF redacting changes" MR from 6 days ago. I'm changing the status accordingly but am at the moment not available to evaluate severity of the report.

@zerotea -- thank you!

with regards to the severity, I've evaluated it as `Medium` but looking at the similarity of an old resolved and disclosed report, you may want to check if this can be consider as `High` severity. I've listed below the similar reports where redacted strings can still be viewed by anyone for your reference.

[Internal attachments can be exported via "Export as .zip" feature](https://hackerone.com/reports/186230) - `High 7.5`
[Partial disclosure of report activity through new "Export as .zip" feature](https://hackerone.com/reports/182358) - `High 7.5`

Hope that helps for your severity evaluation.
@zerotea - Can you change the title to `Redacted username disclosure in "Export as .pdf" feature` ? Thanks
Hi @zerotea - It's been a week, do we have updates on the severity and the bounty ? Thanks
@zerotea - any chance giving an updates ? thanks
Hi @security @zerotea - It's been 10 days already since the report was validated and `Triage`. HackerOne usually do reward bounties upon Triage, Do we have any updates on this ?

Hi @security

The vulnerability was fixed 19 days ago, I was wondering if we have any updates on the severity and the bounty.

HackerOne usually award bounties on `Triage`, additionally average time to bounty is supposed to be 10 days.

Any updates please ?
@security @zerotea - any chance giving an updates on this ?
@security Hello, updates please ?

Hi @japz 

Sorry for the slow response, we're a bit overloaded lately and indeed, usually we award bounties on `triage` so seems this one fell through somehow. 

About the severity, I actually think it should be `low`. The important factor here is the type of data that is accessible with this hack. In this case the only thing that would be leaking is usernames, and that's public information anyway. Next to that you will the person creating the export already had access to the data and thus does not gain any knowledge extra. This will bring the `confidentiality` part of the severity to low and the total severity too.

I will go ahead and update this and move the report forward.

Happy Hacking!
Only public usernames would be leaked if someone were to share the pdf.
Thanks again for bringing this to our attention, it's much appreciated!
Thanks again for bringing this to our attention, it's much appreciated!
Thanks again for bringing this to our attention, it's much appreciated!
Thanks again for bringing this to our attention, it's much appreciated!

Hi @rutger77 - I disagree with the severity being `Low` here, @jobert always mentioned that any report details that was redacted and was __disclosed__ should bump the Confidentiality into `High`.

Additionally, the user required is subjective because the main purpose of .pdf report is actually really for sharing to teams/person/third party.

In history of hackerone disclosed report, most of the time redacted strings and or username is rated as `High` or `Medium` severity. Please see some reference below:

[Internal attachments can be exported via "Export as .zip" feature - High 7.5](https://hackerone.com/reports/186230)
[Partial disclosure of report activity through new "Export as .zip" feature - High 7.5](https://hackerone.com/reports/182358)


Kindly consider rechecking it's severity.

Awaiting for your response.

Thanks
@japz

@rutger77 

>Only public usernames would be leaked if someone were to share the pdf.

__When the strings is redacted, it is not public anymore!, redacted directly means PRIVATE and should not be disclosed/visible.__

It doesn't matter weather it's username, the fact that redacted strings that was part if the report was disclosed, the confidentiality should be `High`. 

It defeats the purpose of __redacted__ feature.

Doesn't mean the feature was reverted which completely fix the issue, means you are going to put it in a `Low` severity.

Please evaluate the impact fairly.

Additional reference which is `Medium`: [Reading redacted data via hackbot's answers](https://hackerone.com/reports/247628)

@zerotea - Can you chime in ?

>The important factor here is the type of data that is accessible with this hack. In this case the only thing that would be leaking is usernames, and that's public information anyway.

The fact that the data is redacted, the purpose is to not be able to read the data and it becomes private. It doesn't matter if it is username, the moment a person redacted it, means they don't want others to see the data.

>Next to that you will the person creating the export already had access to the data and thus does not gain any knowledge extra. This will bring the confidentiality part of the severity to low and the total severity too.

You misunderstand the attack scenario and impact, it's not the person who generated the report who will gain extra knowledge, it's the person who received the shared .pdf report

The person who share the report will think that he already redacted the data and no one will know all the involve usernames (for some reason) , but upon sharing the .pdf file they don't know that the data (usernames) still leaking to 3rd party, it could be anyone who will have extra knowledge on the redacted data.

@rutger77 - Please redact/removed the video PoC before disclosing because it contains undisclosed report. Again, I disagree with how you evaluate the severity and impact here. Kindly read my above comments.

Hi @japz - together in collaboration with Rutger we agreed at the time that it seemed like a Low for confidentiality.

From my perspective, I evaluated it from a bigger picture (leaking an username is not really that concerning), but we as Security Engineers don't always look at isolated components and the intent of the feature. For what it's worth, the fact the feature was reverted did not play into my evaluation on whether it's confidentiality should be high or low. 

I think your feedback is valid, and we'll take it with the security squad for evaluation on basis of your feedback. I'll post back when we reach consensus.

Hi @japz 

We really appreciate your feedback and understand our process has been disappointing, long waiting and not knowing what you're up to. We should do better and come back to you earlier.

We've discussed this internally together with @jobert and we came to the conclusion that the confidentiality part of this should stay at `low`.  One username, from the original reporter, was leaked in a small not commonly used feature. The value of the PII exposed was not high. 

Looking forward to your next submissions.

Best regards,

@rutger77

Hi @rutger77 

Even on the final comments, It looks that you guys missed out to evaluate the whole impact (see my below comment)

>One username, from the original reporter, was leaked in a small not commonly used feature. The value of the PII exposed was not high. 

It's actually __NOT__ one username, the leaked data is not only the reporter's username but almost all usernames in the report. I just took the header part as PoC which you believed it's only the reporter who's username was leaked.

But if you will take a look the the whole report, all usernames was leaked that time, it's my bad I didn't took screenshot of all usernames because I thought that time you guys know already the affected areas.

If you will observed, I even commented that tagging of usernames is already affected [here](#activity-22788258).

But anyways, it's still up to you guys. I still believed this report's severity was evaluated unfairly.

Let's disclosed the report for http://h1.nobbd.de/, please redact also all the screenshot attachment because it leaks the title of my other undisclosed report.

Thanks
@japz

Additionally, the phrase "`was leaked in a small not commonly used feature`" is not an acceptable excuse for evaluation of severity, this is not commonly used feature because it was newly deployed feature, you guys should be thankful i catched that vulnerability earlier after deployment which leads you to revert the deployed feature and completely removed for now so it cannot be exploited. I have seen other disclosed reports that you guys really appreciate the researcher catching the vulnerability earlier after a specific new feature was deployed.

To back up my claim that __"NOT only the researchers name was leaked"__, I reviewed my saved video recording and good thing I found this one which will backup my claim for proof, and good thing here and a little ironic is that you @rutger77 is the one recorded in my video proof, your username was leaked after redacted all usernames, this will show you that not only one (reporter username) was leaking. Please see below:

██████████

I'm not sure if this will change your mind, but let's disclosed the report because I am also writing my blog about this to share with the community.

Thanks
@japz

Hi @japz 

Thanks again for reaching out, and nice find to have myself in the demo video. But still this does not change our point of view on it.

Have a great weekend!

@rutger77
I made the items requested private and added a summary at the top; will check back in on Monday and check thoroughly for lingering items before approving the disclosure request.
@zerotea @security - my write up is now published: https://bugbountyhunter.xyz/redacted-usernames-disclosure-in-export-as-pdf-feature
Thanks! I was on PTO on Monday and forgot about that on Friday so a slight miscommunication, anyway - I checked and looks good to me. Disclosing!

Please disregard this comment below:

Test @hackforgood tagged
Test hackforgood string
Test `hackforgood` string

summaries.content: During a period of roughly week we had deployed a feature that would let you redact usernames in the Export PDF function that did not account for a number of edge cases including nullability, short names, and a few other edge cases. The function did not perform what it was aiming to do, and was reverted thereafter, during that time the hacker identified one of such edge cases and filed the below report.

user.name: zerotea
user.bio: Hacker, Board Games enthousiast, mostly human and definitely not a robot. Software Engineer at HackerOne. They/them
